awd_titl_txt: ICN-WEN: Collaborative Research: SPLICE: Secure Predictive Low-Latency Information Centric Edge for Next Generation Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The fifth generation of wireless communication promises to provide Gigabits per second data transfer rates and communication delays of less than a millisecond. Significant challenges must be overcome in designing a system architecture such that data intensive and/or latency sensitive applications can obtain the information that they need for peak performance. Information-Centric Networking (ICN) has the potential to enable wireless efficiencies that are critical to support the strict guarantees desired by new applications such as virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR) or the control of swarms of unmanned autonomous vehicles (UAVs). The goal of this project is to design, develop and demonstrate SPLICE, a Secure Predictive Low-Latency Information-Centric Edge wireless network that will be able to provide information guarantees to these emerging applications. The project will also contribute to workforce development by means of curriculum development in this domain and recruitment of students from under-represented groups in STEM.

The proposed work is anchored in an ICN implementation called Named Data Networking (NDN), which will be able to effectively tie together application demands and wireless links. The research is organized into three inter-dependent thrusts: (i) Applications for an Information-Centric Wireless Edge: This thrust will define the performance criteria and determine the architecture of the focus application of the project: VR/AR. It will exploit multiple dimensions of commonality between instances of such applications through fast content caching and retrieval, and multicast services. (ii) ICN for the Wireless Edge: explore how information exchange via caching and markets would be accomplished, and how to design secure and privacy-preserving data transfer methods. A key novelty is the use of proactive secure caching that learns the value of applications and ensures they are cached ahead of demand. (iii) Wireless Communication for Information-Centric Networks: employ multicasting capabilities of wireless communication while simultaneously achieving low-delay guarantees and low-complexity feedback mechanisms, via a mix of coding, caching and scheduling techniques.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to design, develop and demonstrate SPLICE, a Secure Predictive Low-Latency Information-Centric Edge wireless network that is able to provide information guarantees to emerging applications such as augmented reality applications, which bring together a desire for information with struct performance guarantees, while operating over an edge wireless network.  The work was anchored in an information-centric network implementation called Named Data Networking (NDN), which tied together application demands and wireless links. The research was organized into three inter-dependent thrusts:

(i) Applications for an Information-Centric Wireless Edge: This defined the performance criteria and determined the architecture of the focus application of the project, naley virtual reality.  We exploited multiple dimensions of commonality between instances of such applications through fast content caching and retrieval, multicast services, and various forms of sensing to ultimately enable a truly mobile VR/AR experience.

(ii) ICN for the Wireless Edge: We explored how information exchange via caching and markets would be accomplished, and how to design secure and privacy-preserving data transfer methods. A key novelty was the use of proactive secure caching that learns the value of applications and ensures they are cached ahead of demand.

(iii) Wireless Communication for Information-Centric Networks: We exploited the multicasting capabilities of wireless communication while simultaneously achieving low-delay guarantees and low-complexity feedback mechanisms, via a mix of coding, caching and scheduling techniques. 

The Washington University team's primary contributions to the outcomes of this collaborative project were in the namespace deisgn supporting AR/VR applications and in the deisgn and evaluation of novel NDN-based mechanisms for low-latency, push-like communication patterns in the form of two protocols, ICT-Notify and ICT-Sync. 

This collaborative project also informed and educated both students and the broader technical community with curriculum development on courses on wireless networking, content distribution methods and outreach to high school students via summer camps.  Several female and minority students were involved in aspects of the project ranging from working on course projects to graduate theses.  Thus, the project also played a role in the integration of under-represented groups to the scientific community. 


Last Modified: 08/14/2022
Modified by: Patrick Crowley
